posts.name: Peter
posts.cooked: Pretty simple. If you were building a virtual four-bar, would you use a timing belt or a chain? What makes one more applicable than the other?

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: Chain, without question, on any virtual four-bar arm that will have a load on the end of it. The sprockets prevent slippage which would otherwise cause the end of the arm to slip out of the desired orientation. It’s not that belts won’t work, but the first time your intake on the end gets hit or bumps too hard into the grid, you’re out of alignment, maybe more than will allow it to function. Why take the risk when it won’t save you much weight?

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Strategic:

It’s not that belts won’t work, but the first time your intake on the end gets hit or bumps too hard into the grid, you’re out of alignment,

I would tend to disagree, because the question was asking specifically about timing belts. I’ve not had issues with properly tensioned timing belts exiting alignment. (We won’t talk about untensioned timing belts.)

Thad said I’d go with a chain, for a combination of strength, packaging (narrower for same strength), and it’s even less likely to misalign.

posts.name: Daniel Kou
posts.cooked: It depends. If the arm isn’t too long, a belt can work, but a chain is more sturdy(and it’s easier to replace). On longer arms, a chain would be better. Just remember to add an adjustable tensioner because even if you have perfect center to center distance, both belts and chains expand over time.

posts.name: Peyton Yeung
posts.cooked: I’d say probably chain for FRC given the existence of inline chain tensioners like this and this .

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: I’m just not visualizing how those work.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: They just go inbetween a pair of master links, acting like a turnbuckle on a rope.

posts.name: Luin
posts.cooked: If a loop of chain doesnt do a full rotation around a sprocket, you can put one of those bad boys in the loop. It bolts between the two ends of the chain loop and pulls them together. This means that you dont necessarily need to have proper chain tensioning as you have the fine adjustment of the screw. It also helps when your chain stretches a little bit, you just tighten it up a bit more and it’s tensioned again.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Ok, so it only works in a situation where it won’t touch any sprockets?   That makes more sense, thanks!

posts.name: Luin
posts.cooked:
yep that’s correct. And if it does touch… well… I certainly wouldnt know, but its not fun if you dont have a spare sprocket XD

edit: Spelling

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
For long runs it may make sense to replace much of the chain with wire rope.

Strongly agree that an inline tensioner is used, especially with how the tolerance stack over a bigger assembly like this can work out.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Or even better imo Dyneema rope. Stronger and lighter for the same diameter of wire rope.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: When we have used dyneema in constant-tension applications like this we have found that it relaxes, or something in the system relaxed (or maybe it was a set, I’m not sure of the specific mechanism). Now, maybe it can be implemented better than we did, but be aware that dyneema losing tension over time is a potential issue. Maybe a better batch of cord or a larger diameter than what we used (1.6mm) will solve the issue.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Knots and splices will tighten up and create a bit of slack sometimes (another reason to look up the proper knot for your application, bowlines in this case)  it will relax slightly and become stiffer as the fibers settle in.  However the stretch on dynamics very low, so as long as there is a tensioning mechanism in the system there should be zero issues.

posts.name: system
